ContentsPblock.ContentsTitle: Parliamentary control of statutory instruments under FSMA 2000

ContentsItem.ContentsTitle: Accounts of Bank of England and its wholly-owned subsidiaries

Para.Text: Make further provision about banking and other financial services, including provision about the Financial Services Compensation Scheme; to make provision for the amounts owed in respect of certain deposits to be treated as a preferential debt on insolvency; to make provision about the accounts of the Bank of England and its wholly owned subsidiaries; and for connected purposes.

Be it enacted by the Queen’s most Excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, as follows:—

P2para.Text: Section 2B of FSMA 2000 (the PRA’s general objective) is amended as follows.
In subsection (3)—

P3para.Text: at the end of paragraph (a), omit “and”, and
after paragraph (b) insert
discharging its general functions in relation to the matters mentioned in subsection (4A) in a way that seeks to—

P4para.Text: ensure that the business of ring-fenced bodies is carried on in a way that avoids any adverse effect on the continuity of the provision in the United Kingdom of core services,

ensure that the business of ring-fenced bodies is protected from risks (arising in the United Kingdom or elsewhere) that could adversely affect the continuity of the provision in the United Kingdom of core services, and
minimise the risk that the failure of a ring-fenced body could affect the continuity of the provision in the United Kingdom of core services.

P2para.Text: In subsection (4) for “subsection (3)” substitute “subsection (3)(a) and (b)”.
After subsection (4) insert—
The matters referred to in subsection (3)(c) are—

P3para.Text: Part 9B (ring-fencing);
ring-fenced bodies (see section 142A);
any body corporate incorporated in the United Kingdom that has a ring-fenced body as a member of its group;
applications under Part 4A which, if granted, would result, or would be capable of resulting, in a person becoming a ring-fenced body.

P1group.Title: Modification of objectives of Financial Conduct Authority

P1para.Text: After section 1I of FSMA 2000 insert—

Pblock.Title: Modifications applying if core activity not regulated by PRA

P1group.Title: Modifications applying if core activity not regulated by PRA

P2para.Text: If and so long as any regulated activity is a core activity (see section 142B) without also being a PRA-regulated activity (see section 22A), the provisions of this Chapter are to have effect subject to the following modifications.
Section 1B is to have effect as if—

P3para.Text: in subsection (3) after paragraph (c) there were inserted—
in relation to the matters mentioned in section 1EA(2), the continuity objective (see section 1EA).
in subsection (4), for “or the integrity objective,” there were substituted “, the integrity objective or (in relation to the matters mentioned in section 1EA(2)) the continuity objective,”.

P2para.Text: After section 1E there is to be taken to be inserted—
(1)In relation to the matters mentioned in subsection (2), the continuity objective is: protecting the continuity of the provision in the United Kingdom of core services (see section 142C).
(2)Those matters are—

P3para.Text: Part 9B (ring-fencing);
ring-fenced bodies (see section 142A);
any body corporate incorporated in the United Kingdom that has a ring-fenced body as a member of its group;
applications under Part 4A which, if granted, would result, or would be capable of resulting, in a person becoming a ring-fenced body.

P2para.Text: (3)The FCA’s continuity objective is to be advanced primarily by—

P3para.Text: seeking to ensure that the business of ring-fenced bodies is carried on in a way that avoids any adverse effect on the
continuity of the provision in the United Kingdom of core services,

seeking to ensure that the business of ring-fenced bodies is protected from risks (arising in the United Kingdom or elsewhere) that could adversely affect the continuity of the provision in the United Kingdom of core services, and
seeking to minimise the risk that the failure of a ring-fenced body could adversely affect the continuity of the provision in the United Kingdom of core services.

P1group.Title: Amendment of PRA power of direction

P1para.Text: In section 3I of FSMA 2000 (power of PRA to require FCA to refrain from specified action), in subsection (4)—

P3para.Text: at the end of paragraph (a), omit “or”, and
at the end of paragraph (b) insert
threaten the continuity of core services provided in the United Kingdom.

P2para.Text: After Part 9A of FSMA 2000 insert—
In this Act “ring-fenced body” means a UK institution which carries on one or more core activities (see section 142B) in relation to which it has a Part 4A permission.
But “ring-fenced body” does not include—

P3para.Text: a building society within the meaning of the Building Societies Act 1986, or
a UK institution of a class exempted by order made by the Treasury.

P2para.Text: An order under subsection (2)(b) may be made in relation to a class of UK institution only if the Treasury are of the opinion that the exemption conferred by the order would not be likely to have a significant adverse effect on the continuity of the provision in the United Kingdom of core services.
An order under subsection (2)(b) may provide for the exemption to be subject to conditions.
In this section “UK institution” means a body corporate incorporated in the United Kingdom.
References in this Act to a “core activity” are to be read in accordance with this section.
The regulated activity of accepting deposits (whether carried on in the United Kingdom or elsewhere) is a core activity unless it is carried on in circumstances specified by the Treasury by order.

An order under subsection (2) may be made only if the Treasury are of the opinion that it is not necessary for either of the following purposes that the regulated activity of accepting deposits should be a core activity when carried on in the specified circumstances.
Those purposes are—

P3para.Text: to secure an appropriate degree of protection for the depositors concerned, or
to protect the continuity of the provision in the United Kingdom of services provided in the course of carrying on the regulated activity of accepting deposits.

P2para.Text: The Treasury may by order provide for a regulated activity other than that of accepting deposits to be a core activity, either generally or when carried on in circumstances specified in the order.
An order under subsection (5) may be made only if the Treasury are of the opinion—

P3para.Text: that an interruption of the provision of services provided in the United Kingdom in the carrying on of the regulated activity concerned could adversely affect the stability of the UK financial system or of a significant part of that system, and
that the continuity of the provision of those services can more effectively be protected by treating the activity as a core activity.

P2para.Text: References in this Act to “core services” are to be read in accordance with this section.
The following are core services—

P3para.Text: facilities for the accepting of deposits or other payments into an account which is provided in the course of carrying on the core activity of accepting deposits;
facilities for withdrawing money or making payments from such an account;
overdraft facilities in connection with such an account.

P2para.Text: The Treasury may by order provide that any other specified services provided in the course of carrying on the core activity of accepting deposits are also core services.

If an order under section 142B(5) provides for an activity other than that of accepting deposits to be a core activity, the Treasury must by order provide that specified services provided in the course of carrying on that activity are core services.
The services specified by order under subsection (4) must be services in relation to which the Treasury are of the opinion mentioned in section 142B(6)(a).
References in this Act to an “excluded activity” are to be read in accordance with this section.

The regulated activity of dealing in investments as principal (whether carried on in the United Kingdom or elsewhere) is an excluded activity unless it is carried on in circumstances specified by the Treasury by order.

An order under subsection (2) may be made only if the Treasury are of the opinion that allowing ring-fenced bodies to deal in investments as principal in the specified circumstances would not be likely to result in any significant adverse effect on the continuity of the provision in the United Kingdom of core services.

The Treasury may by order provide for an activity other than the regulated activity of dealing in investments as principal to be an excluded activity, either generally or when carried on in circumstances specified in the order.
An activity to which an order under subsection (4) relates—

P3para.Text: need not be a regulated activity, and
may be an activity carried on in the United Kingdom or elsewhere.

P2para.Text: In deciding whether to make an order under subsection (4) in relation to any activity, the Treasury must—

P3para.Text: have regard to the risks to which a ring-fenced body would be exposed if it carried on the activity concerned, and

consider whether the carrying on of that activity by a ring-fenced body would make it more likely that the failure of the body would have an adverse effect on the continuity of the provision in the United Kingdom of core services.

P2para.Text: An order under subsection (4) may be made only if the Treasury are of the opinion that the making of the order is necessary or expedient for the purpose of protecting the continuity of the provision in the United Kingdom of core services.

P1group.Title: Power of Treasury to impose prohibitions

P2para.Text: The Treasury may by order prohibit ring-fenced bodies from—

P3para.Text: entering into transactions of a specified kind or with persons falling within a specified class;
establishing or maintaining a branch in a specified country or territory;
holding in specified circumstances shares or voting power in companies of a specified description.

P2para.Text: In deciding whether to make an order under this section imposing a prohibition, the Treasury must—

P3para.Text: have regard to the risks to which a ring-fenced body would be exposed if it did the thing to which the prohibition relates, and

consider whether the doing of that thing by a ring-fenced body would make it more likely that the failure of the body would have an adverse effect on the continuity of the provision in the United Kingdom of core services.

P2para.Text: An order under this section may be made only if the Treasury are of the opinion that the making of the order is necessary or expedient for the purpose of protecting the continuity of the provision in the United Kingdom of core services.
An order under this section may in particular—

P3para.Text: provide for any prohibition to be subject to exemptions specified in the order;
provide for any exemption to be subject to conditions specified in the order.

P2para.Text: An order made under section 142A, 142B, 142D or 142E may—

P3para.Text: authorise or require the making of rules by a regulator for the purposes of, or connected with, any provision of the order;
authorise the making of other instruments by a regulator for the purposes of, or connected with, any provision of the order;
refer to a publication issued by a regulator, another body in the United Kingdom or an international organisation, as the publication has effect from time to time.

P2para.Text: If the order confers powers on a regulator or authorises or requires the making of rules or other instruments by a regulator, the order may also—

P3para.Text: impose conditions on the exercise of any power conferred on the regulator;
impose consultation requirements on the regulator;
make the exercise of a power by the regulator subject to the consent of the Treasury.

Pblock.Title: Ring-fenced bodies not to carry on excluded activities or contravene prohibitions

P1group.Title: Ring-fenced bodies not to carry on excluded activities or contravene prohibitions

P2para.Text: A ring-fenced body which—

P3para.Text: carries on an excluded activity or purports to do so, or
contravenes any provision of an order under section 142E,

P2para.Text: is to be taken to have contravened a requirement imposed on the body by the appropriate regulator under this Act.

P3para.Text: carries on an excluded activity or purports to do so, or
contravenes any provision of an order under section 142E,

P2para.Text: is to be taken to have contravened a requirement imposed on the body by the appropriate regulator under this Act.
The contravention does not—

P3para.Text: make a person guilty of an offence;
make a transaction void or unenforceable;
(subject to subsection (3)) give rise to any right of action for breach of statutory duty.

P2para.Text: In such cases as the Treasury may specify by order, the contravention is actionable at the suit of a person who suffers loss as a result of the contravention, subject to the defences and other incidents applying to actions for breach of statutory duty.
In this section “the appropriate regulator” means—

P3para.Text: in relation to a ring-fenced body which is a PRA-authorised person, the PRA;
in relation to any other ring-fenced body, the FCA.

P2para.Text: In the exercise of its power to make general rules, the appropriate regulator must in particular make rules—

P3para.Text: requiring a ring-fenced body to make arrangements to ensure the effective provision to the ring-fenced body of services and facilities that it requires in relation to the carrying on of a core activity, and
making provision for the group ring-fencing purposes applying to ring-fenced bodies and to authorised persons who are members of a ring-fenced body’s group.

P2para.Text: Section 142E(1)(c) does not affect the power of the appropriate regulator to make general rules imposing restrictions on the extent of the shares or voting power that a ring-fenced body may hold in another company, except where a restriction on the extent of the shares or voting power that the ring-fenced body may hold in the company is imposed by order under section 142E(1)(c).
General rules that are required by this section or make provision falling within subsection (2) are in this Act referred to as “ring-fencing rules”.
The “group ring-fencing purposes” are—

P3para.Text: ensuring as far as reasonably practicable that the carrying on of core activities by a ring-fenced body is not adversely affected by the acts or omissions of other members of its group;
ensuring as far as reasonably practicable that in carrying on its business a ring-fenced body—

P4para.Text: is able to take decisions independently of other members of its group, and
does not depend on resources which are provided by a member of its group and which would cease to be available to the ring-fenced body in the event of the insolvency of the other member;

P3para.Text: ensuring as far as reasonably practicable that the ring-fenced body would be able to continue to carry on core activities in the event of the insolvency of one or more other members of its group.

P2para.Text: Ring-fencing rules made for the group ring-fencing purposes must include—

P3para.Text: provision restricting the power of a ring-fenced body to enter into contracts with other members of its group otherwise than on arm’s length terms;
provision restricting the payments that a ring-fenced body may make (by way of dividend or otherwise) to other members of its group;
provision requiring the disclosure to the appropriate regulator of information relating to transactions between a ring-fenced body and other members of its group;
provision requiring a ring-fenced body to ensure that its board of directors (or if there is no such board, the equivalent management body) includes to a specified extent—

P4para.Text: members who are treated by the rules as being independent of other members of the ring-fenced body’s group,
members who are treated by the rules as being independent of the ring-fenced body itself, and

P3para.Text: provision requiring a ring-fenced body to act in accordance with a remuneration policy meeting specified requirements;
provision requiring a ring-fenced body to act in accordance with a human resources policy meeting specified requirements;
provision requiring arrangements made by the ring-fenced body for the identification, monitoring and management of risk to meet specified requirements;
such other provision as the appropriate regulator considers necessary or expedient for any of the purposes in subsection (4).

P2para.Text: The reference in subsection (5)(e) to a remuneration policy is a reference to a policy about the remuneration of officers, employees and other persons who (in each case) are of a specified description.

The reference in subsection (5)(f) to a human resources policy is a reference to a policy about the appointment and management of officers, employees and other persons who (in each case) are of a specified description.
In this section—

Para.Text: “the appropriate regulator” means—
in relation to a ring-fenced body which is a PRA-authorised person, the PRA;
in relation to any other ring-fenced body, the FCA;
“shares” has the meaning given in section 422;
“specified” means specified in the rules;
“voting power” has the meaning given in section 422.

P1group.Title: Powers of Treasury in relation to ring-fencing rules

P2para.Text: The Treasury may by order require the appropriate regulator, as defined in section 142H(8), to include (or not to include) in ring-fencing rules specified provision relating to—

P3para.Text: any of the matters mentioned in section 142H(5)(a) to (g), or
any other specified matter.

P2para.Text: The power to make an order under this section is exercisable only if the Treasury consider it necessary or expedient to do so—

P3para.Text: for any of the group ring-fencing purposes as defined in section 142H(4), or
otherwise for securing the independence of ring-fenced bodies from other members of their groups.

P2para.Text: “Specified” means specified in the order.
The PRA must carry out reviews of its ring-fencing rules.
The first review must be completed before the end of the period of 5 years beginning with the day on which the first ring-fencing rules come into force.
Subsequent reviews must be completed before the end of the period of 5 years beginning with the day on which the previous review was completed.
The PRA must give the Treasury a report of each review.
The Treasury must lay a copy of the report before Parliament.
The PRA must publish the report in such manner as it thinks fit.

If (because any ring-fenced body is not a PRA-authorised person) section 142H has the effect of requiring the FCA to make ring-fencing rules, subsections (1) to (6) apply to the FCA as they apply to the PRA.
For the purposes of this section an occupational pension scheme is a “relevant pension scheme” if—

P3para.Text: it is a multi-employer scheme, as defined in section 75A(13) of the Pensions Act 1995 or Article 75A(13) of the Pensions (Northern Ireland) Order 1995,
it is not a money purchase scheme,
at least one of the employers in relation to the scheme is a ring-fenced body, and
at least one of the employers in relation to the scheme is not a ring-fenced body.

P2para.Text: The Treasury may by regulations—

P3para.Text: require a ring-fenced body which is an employer in relation to a relevant pension scheme to make arrangements for the purpose of—

P4para.Text: ensuring that the ring-fenced body cannot become liable to meet, or contribute to the meeting of, liabilities in respect of pensions or other benefits payable to or in respect of employment by a person who is not a ring-fenced body, and
to the extent that it is not possible to ensure that result, minimising any potential liability falling within sub-paragraph (i);

P3para.Text: make other provision about the making of arrangements for that purpose by a ring-fenced body which is an employer in relation to a relevant pension scheme.

P2para.Text: The regulations may in particular—

P3para.Text: require a ring-fenced body to cease to participate in a relevant pension scheme unless the scheme is divided into two or more sections in relation to which prescribed conditions are met;

provide that assets or liabilities of a relevant pension scheme may not be transferred under the arrangements to another occupational pension scheme unless the other scheme meets prescribed conditions;
require ring-fenced bodies to establish new occupational pension schemes in prescribed circumstances;

provide that any provision of a relevant pension scheme that might prevent a ring-fenced body from making the arrangements, other than a provision requiring the consent of the trustees or managers of the scheme, is not to have effect in prescribed circumstances;

make provision enabling the trustees or managers of a relevant pension scheme, with the consent of the employers in relation to the scheme, to modify the scheme by resolution for the purpose of enabling a ring-fenced body to make the arrangements;

make provision enabling the court, on an application made in accordance with the regulations by a ring-fenced body, if it appears to the court that the trustees or managers of a relevant pension scheme, or an employer in relation to such a scheme, have unreasonably refused their consent to any step that would enable the ring-fenced body to make the arrangements, to order that the step may be taken without that consent;
require a ring-fenced body to make an application for clearance in connection with the making of the arrangements;
confer exemption from any provision of the regulations in prescribed cases;
confer functions on the PRA;
provide that a ring-fenced body which contravenes a prescribed requirement of the regulations is to be taken to have contravened a requirement imposed by the PRA under this Act.

P2para.Text: An “application for clearance” is an application to the Pensions Regulator under any of the following provisions—

P3para.Text: section 42 of the Pensions Act 2004 (clearance statements relating to contribution notice under section 38);
section 46 of that Act (clearance statements relating to financial support directions);
Article 38 of the Pensions (Northern Ireland) Order 2005 (clearance statements relating to contribution notices under article 34);
Article 42 of that Order (clearance statements relating to financial support directions).

P2para.Text: In relation to a ring-fenced body that is not a PRA-authorised person, references in subsection (3) to the PRA are to be read as references to the FCA.

The regulations may not require ring-fenced bodies to achieve the results mentioned in subsection (2) before 1 January 2026, but this does not prevent the regulations requiring steps to be taken at any time after the regulations come into force.
The following provisions have effect for the interpretation of section 142K.

“Occupational pension scheme” has the meaning given in section 1 of the Pension Schemes Act 1993 or section 1 of the Pension Schemes (Northern Ireland) Act 1993 and, in relation to such a scheme, “employer”, “member” and “trustees or managers” have the same meaning as in Part 1 of the Pensions Act 1995 or Part 2 of the Pensions (Northern Ireland) Order 1995.
“Money purchase scheme” has the meaning given in section 181(1) of the Pension Schemes Act 1993 or section 176(1) of the Pension Schemes (Northern Ireland) Act 1993.
“The court” means—

P3para.Text: in relation to England and Wales or Northern Ireland, the High Court, and
in relation to Scotland, the Court of Session.

P1group.Title: Power of Treasury in relation to loss-absorbency requirements

P2para.Text: The Treasury may by order make provision about the exercise by either regulator of its functions under this Act, so far as they are (apart from the order) capable of being exercised in relation to a relevant body so as to require the relevant body—

P3para.Text: to issue any debt instrument, or
to ensure that any part of the relevant body’s debt consists of debt owed by it in respect of debt instruments, or debt instruments of a particular kind.

P2para.Text: A “relevant body” is—

P3para.Text: a ring-fenced body,
any other body corporate that has a Part 4A permission relating to the regulated activity of accepting deposits, or
a body corporate that is a member of the group of a body falling within paragraph (a) or (b).

P2para.Text: “Debt instrument” means—

P3para.Text: a bond,
any other instrument creating or acknowledging a debt, or
an instrument giving rights to acquire a debt instrument.

P2para.Text: An order under this section may in particular—

P3para.Text: require the regulator to exercise its functions so as to require relevant bodies to do either or both of the things mentioned in subsection (1);
limit the extent to which the regulator may require a relevant body’s debt to consist of debt owed in respect of debt instruments or of debt instruments of a kind specified in the order;
require the regulator—

P4para.Text: to make, or not to make, provision by reference to specified matters, or
to have regard, or not to have regard, to specified matters;

P3para.Text: require the regulator to consult, or obtain the consent of, the Treasury before making rules of a specified description or exercising any other specified function;
impose on the regulator in connection with the exercise of a specified function procedural requirements which would not otherwise apply to the exercise of the function;
refer to a publication issued by a regulator, another body in the United Kingdom or an international organisation, as the publication has effect from time to time.
limit the extent to which the regulator may require a relevant body’s debt to consist of debt owed in respect of debt instruments or of debt instruments of a kind specified in the order;
require the regulator—

P4para.Text: to make, or not to make, provision by reference to specified matters, or
to have regard, or not to have regard, to specified matters;

P3para.Text: require the regulator to consult, or obtain the consent of, the Treasury before making rules of a specified description or exercising any other specified function;
impose on the regulator in connection with the exercise of a specified function procedural requirements which would not otherwise apply to the exercise of the function;
refer to a publication issued by a regulator, another body in the United Kingdom or an international organisation, as the publication has effect from time to time.

P2para.Text: “Specified” means specified in the order.

P1group.Title: Affirmative procedure in relation to certain orders under Part 9B

P2para.Text: This section applies to an order containing provision made under any of the following provisions of this Part—

P3para.Text: section 142A(2)(b);
section 142B(2) or (5);
section 142C;
section 142D(2) or (4);
section 142E;
section 142I;
section 142M.

P2para.Text: No order to which this section applies may be made unless—

P3para.Text: a draft of the order has been laid before Parliament and approved by a resolution of each House, or
subsection (4) applies.

P2para.Text: Subsection (4) applies if an order under 142D(4) or 142E contains a statement that the Treasury are of the opinion that, by reason of urgency, it is necessary to make the order without a draft being so laid and approved.
Where this subsection applies the order—

P3para.Text: must be laid before Parliament after being made, and
ceases to have effect at the end of the relevant period unless before the end of that period the order is approved by a
resolution of each House of Parliament (but without that affecting anything done under the order or the power to make a new order).

P2para.Text: The “relevant period” is a period of 28 days beginning with the day on which the order is made.
In calculating the relevant period no account is to be taken of any time during which Parliament is dissolved or prorogued or during which either House is adjourned for more than 4 days.

P1para.Text: In this Part, any reference to—

P3para.Text: the regulated activity of accepting deposits, or
the regulated activity of dealing in investments as principal,

P1para.Text: is to be read in accordance with Schedule 2, taken with any order under section 22.

P2para.Text: In section 417 of FSMA 2000 (definitions), in subsection (1)—

P3para.Text: after the definition of “control of information rules” insert—

Para.Text: “core activities” has the meaning given in section 142B;
“core services” has the meaning given in section 142C;

P3para.Text: after the definition of “ESMA” insert—

Para.Text: “excluded activities” has the meaning given in section 142D;

P3para.Text: after the definition of “regulator” insert—

Para.Text: “ring-fenced body” has the meaning given in section 142A;
“ring-fencing rules” has the meaning given in section 142H;

P1group.Title: Directors of ring-fenced bodies to be approved persons

P1para.Text: In section 59 of FSMA 2000 (approval for particular arrangements) after subsection (7B) insert—

P2para.Text: In relation to a ring-fenced body, the function of acting as a director (or, where the ring-fenced body does not have a board of directors, as a member of its equivalent management body)—

P3para.Text: is a significant-influence function, and
must be specified as a controlled function by rules made—

P4para.Text: in relation to ring-fenced bodies that are PRA-authorised persons, by the PRA, or
in relation to other ring-fenced bodies, by the FCA.

P2para.Text: In Schedule 1ZB to FSMA 2000 (the Prudential Regulation Authority), paragraph 19 (annual report) is amended as follows.
After sub-paragraph (1) insert—
In the report the PRA must also report in general terms on—

P3para.Text: the extent to which, in its opinion, ring-fenced bodies have complied with the ring-fencing provisions,
steps taken by ring-fenced bodies in order to comply with the ring-fencing provisions,
steps taken by it to enforce the ring-fencing provisions, and

the extent to which ring-fenced bodies appear to it to have acted in accordance with any guidance which it has given to ring-fenced bodies and which relates to the operation of the ring-fencing provisions.

P2para.Text: In sub-paragraph (1A)—

P3para.Text: references to “ring-fenced bodies” relate only to ring-fenced bodies that are PRA-authorised persons, and
“the ring-fencing provisions” means ring-fencing rules and the duty imposed as a result of section 142G.

P2para.Text: In sub-paragraph (2), for “Sub-paragraph (1) does not” substitute “Sub-paragraphs (1) and (1A) do not”.”

P1para.Text: The Schedule (which contains amendments of Part 7 of FSMA 2000 relating to ring-fencing transfer schemes) has effect.

P1group.Title: Building societies: power to make provision about ring-fencing

P2para.Text: The Treasury may by regulations—

P3para.Text: make provision in relation to building societies for purposes corresponding to those of any provision made, in relation to authorised persons other than building societies, by or under any provision of Part 9B of FSMA 2000 (ring-fencing) apart from sections 142K to 142M, and

provide for the application of the relevant continuity provision in relation to the exercise by the FCA or the PRA of any function conferred on it by or under provision made pursuant to paragraph (a).

P2para.Text: The regulations may, in particular—

P3para.Text: amend the Building Societies Act 1986;
apply any of the provisions contained in, or made under, Part 9B of FSMA 2000, with such modifications as the Treasury consider appropriate;
authorise the making of rules or other instruments by the FCA or the PRA for the purposes of, or connected with, any provision made by the regulations;
confer functions on the FCA or the PRA;
make such consequential provision including amendments of any enactment as the Treasury consider appropriate.

P2para.Text: This section does not affect the application of section 142M of FSMA 2000 (power of Treasury in relation to loss-absorbency requirements) to building societies that are relevant bodies for the purposes of that section.
In this section—

Para.Text: “building society” has the same meaning as in the Building Societies Act 1986;
“the relevant continuity provision” means—
in the case of functions exercisable by the FCA, the continuity objective set out in section 1EA of FSMA 2000, or
in the case of functions exercisable by the PRA, section 2B(3)(c) and (4A) of that Act.

P2para.Text: In Schedule 6 to the Insolvency Act 1986 (categories of preferential debts) after paragraph 15A insert—

P1group.Title: Category 7: Deposits covered by Financial Services Compensation Scheme

P1para.Text: So much of any amount owed at the relevant date by the debtor in respect of an eligible deposit as does not exceed the compensation that would be payable in respect of the deposit under the Financial Services Compensation Scheme to the person or persons to whom the amount is owed.

P2para.Text: In paragraph 15B “eligible deposit” means a deposit in respect of which the person, or any of the persons, to whom it is owed would be eligible for compensation under the Financial Services Compensation Scheme.
For this purpose a “deposit” means rights of the kind described in—

P3para.Text: paragraph 22 of Schedule 2 to the Financial Services and Markets Act 2000 (deposits), or
section 1(2)(b) of the Dormant Bank and Building Society Accounts Act 2008 (balances transferred under that Act to authorised reclaim fund).

P2para.Text: In section 386 of the Insolvency Act 1986 (categories of preferential debt), in subsection (1), after “production” insert ”;deposits covered by Financial Services Compensation Scheme”.
In Part 1 of Schedule 3 to the Bankruptcy (Scotland) Act 1985 (list of preferred debts), after paragraph 6A insert—

P1group.Title: Deposits covered by Financial Services Compensation Scheme

P1para.Text: So much of any amount owed at the relevant date by the debtor in respect of an eligible deposit as does not exceed the compensation that would be payable in respect of the deposit under the Financial Services Compensation Scheme to the person or persons to whom the amount is owed.

P2para.Text: In Part 2 of Schedule 3 to the Bankruptcy (Scotland) Act 1985 (interpretation of
Part 1), after paragraph 9 insert—

In paragraph 6B “eligible deposit” means a deposit in respect of which the person, or any of the persons, to whom it is owed would be eligible for compensation under the Financial Services Compensation Scheme.
For this purpose a “deposit” means rights of the kind described in paragraph 22 of Schedule 2 to the Financial Services and Markets Act 2000 (deposits).

P1group.Title: Discharge of functions by the scheme manager

P1para.Text: After section 224 of FSMA 2000 insert—

P2para.Text: In discharging its functions the scheme manager must have regard to—

P3para.Text: the need to ensure efficiency and effectiveness in the discharge of those functions, and
the need to minimise public expenditure attributable to loans made or other financial assistance given to the scheme manager for the purposes of the scheme.

P2para.Text: In subsection (1)(b) “financial assistance” includes the giving of guarantees and indemnities and any other kind of financial assistance (actual or contingent).

P1group.Title: Power to require information from scheme manager

P1para.Text: After section 218A of FSMA 2000 insert—

P1group.Title: Treasury’s power to require information from scheme manager

P2para.Text: The Treasury may by notice in writing require the scheme manager to provide specified information or information of a specified description that the Treasury reasonably require in connection with the duties of the Treasury under the Government Resources and Accounts Act 2000.
Information required under this section must be provided before the end of such reasonable period as may be specified.
“Specified” means specified in the notice.

P1group.Title: Scheme manager: appointment of accounting officer

P2para.Text: Section 212 of FSMA 2000 (the scheme manager of the Financial Services Compensation Scheme) is amended as follows.
In subsection (3)—

P3para.Text: omit the “and” following paragraph (a),
after that paragraph insert—
a chief executive (who is to be the accounting officer); and
in paragraph (b), after “chairman” insert “and chief executive”.

P2para.Text: In subsection (4)—

P3para.Text: after “chairman”, in the first place, insert “, chief executive”, and
after “chairman”, in the second place, insert “and the chief executive”.

P1group.Title: Fees to meet Treasury expenditure relating to international organisations

P1para.Text: After section 410 of FSMA 2000 insert—

P1group.Title: Fees to meet certain expenses of the Treasury

P2para.Text: The Treasury may by regulations—

P3para.Text: enable the Treasury from time to time by direction to require the FCA, the PRA or the Bank of England (each a “regulator”) to require the payment of fees by relevant persons, or such class of relevant person as may be specified in, or determined by the regulator in accordance with, the direction, for the purpose of meeting relevant expenses incurred by the Treasury;
make provision about how the regulator to which a direction is given is to comply with the direction;
require the regulator to pay to the Treasury, by such time or times as may be specified in the direction, the amount of any fees received by the regulator.

P2para.Text: “Relevant expenses” are expenses (including any expenses of a capital nature) which are attributable to United Kingdom membership of, or Treasury participation in, a prescribed international organisation so far as those expenses—

P3para.Text: represent a contribution (by way of subscription or otherwise) to the resources of the international organisation, and
are in the opinion of the Treasury attributable to functions of the organisation which relate to financial stability or financial services.

P2para.Text: The regulations must provide for the charging of fees in pursuance of a direction given under the regulations to the FCA or the PRA to be by rules made by that regulator.
The provisions of Chapter 2 of Part 9A apply to rules of the FCA or the PRA providing for the charging of fees in pursuance of a direction given under the regulations—

P3para.Text: in the case of the FCA, as they apply to rules relating to the payment of fees under paragraph 23 of Schedule 1ZA;
in the case of the PRA, as they apply to rules relating to the payment of fees under paragraph 31 of Schedule 1ZB.

P2para.Text: Paragraph 36(1) of Schedule 17A applies to the charging of fees by the Bank of England in pursuance of a direction given to the Bank under the regulations.
The regulations may in particular—

P3para.Text: make provision about what is, or is not, to be regarded as an expense;
specify requirements that the Treasury must comply with before giving a direction;
enable a direction to be varied or revoked by a subsequent direction;
confer functions on a regulator.

P2para.Text: An amount payable to a regulator as a result of—

P3para.Text: any provision of rules made by the FCA or the PRA as a result of the regulations, or
the imposition of fees by the Bank of England as a result of a direction given under the regulations to the Bank,

P2para.Text: may be recovered as a debt due to the regulator.
“Relevant persons” means—

P3para.Text: in the case of a direction given to the PRA, PRA-authorised persons;
in the case of a direction given to the FCA, authorised persons and recognised investment exchanges who (in either case) are not PRA-authorised persons;
in the case of a direction given to the Bank of England, recognised clearing houses, other than those falling within paragraph (a) or (b).

P2para.Text: This section is subject to section 410B.
In this section “a fees direction” means a direction given by the Treasury as a result of regulations under section 410A.
Before giving a fees direction to the FCA, the PRA or the Bank of England (each a “regulator”), the Treasury must consult the regulator concerned.
A fees direction must—

P3para.Text: be in writing;

except in the case of a direction that revokes a previous direction or a direction that varies a previous direction without affecting the total amount intended to be raised by the fees, specify the total amount intended to be raised by the fees to be charged by the regulator and explain how that amount is calculated;
contain such other information as may be prescribed.

P2para.Text: As soon as practicable after giving a fees direction, the Treasury must lay before Parliament a copy of the direction.

Pblock.Title: Parliamentary control of statutory instruments under FSMA 2000

P2para.Text: Section 429 of FSMA 2000 (Parliamentary control of statutory instruments) is amended as follows.
In subsection (1)(a) (orders subject to affirmative procedure), for “144(4), 192(b) or (e), 138K(6)(c)” substitute “138K(6)(c), 144(4), 192(b) or (e)”.
In subsection (2) (regulations subject to affirmative procedure), after “90B,” insert “142K,”.
After subsection (2) insert—
Regulations to which subsection (2B) applies are not to be made unless a draft of the regulations has been laid before Parliament and approved by a resolution of each House.
This subsection applies to regulations which contain provision made under section 410A, other than provision made only by virtue of subsection (2) of that section.
In subsection (8), for “or 23A” substitute “, 23A or 142N”.

P1group.Title: Accounts of Bank of England and its wholly-owned subsidiaries

P2para.Text: The Bank of England Act 1998 is amended as follows.
In section 7 (accounts), in subsection (4), for the words from “appropriate” to the end substitute “necessary to do so having regard to the Financial Stability Objective”.
After section 7 insert—

P1group.Title: Accounts of companies wholly owned by the Bank

P2para.Text: If the Bank considers it necessary to do so having regard to the Financial Stability Objective, the Bank may by direction to a qualifying company exclude the application to the qualifying company of any of the relevant Companies Act requirements.

The relevant Companies Act requirements are the requirements to which the directors of the qualifying company would otherwise be subject under the Companies Act 2006 (except sections 412 and 413 (directors’ benefits)) in relation to the preparation of accounts under section 394 of that Act.

A direction under subsection (1) may relate to one or more specified accounting periods of the qualifying company, or to a specified accounting period and all subsequent accounting periods of the qualifying company.
The Bank must consult the Treasury before giving a direction under subsection (1).

The Treasury may by notice in writing to the Bank require it to publish in such manner as it thinks fit such information relating to the accounts of a qualifying company as the Treasury may specify in the notice.

The information specified in a notice under subsection (5) may include information which as a result of a direction under subsection (1) was excluded from accounts prepared in accordance with the Companies Act 2006.
The Treasury must consult the Bank before giving a notice under subsection (5).
A direction under subsection (1) or a notice under subsection (5) may be revoked by a subsequent direction or notice (as the case may be).
“Qualifying company” means any company which is wholly owned by the Bank other than—

P3para.Text: the Prudential Regulation Authority, or
a company which is a bridge bank for the purposes of section 12(3) of the Banking Act 2009.

P2para.Text: For the purposes of subsection (9), a company is wholly owned by the Bank if—

P3para.Text: it is a company of which no person other than the Bank or a nominee of the Bank is a member, or
it is a wholly-owned subsidiary of a company within paragraph (a).

P2para.Text: Any power of the Treasury to make an order or regulations under this Act is exercisable by statutory instrument.

A statutory instrument containing regulations under section 8 (building societies: power to make provision about ring-fencing) may not be made unless a draft of the instrument has been laid before, and approved by a resolution of, each House of Parliament.

A statutory instrument containing an order under section 18 (transitional provisions and savings) is subject to annulment in pursuance of a resolution of either House of Parliament, unless the instrument is required by any enactment to be laid in draft before, and approved by a resolution of, each House.

P1para.Text: In this Act—

Para.Text: “enactment” includes—
an enactment contained in subordinate legislation,
an enactment contained in, or in an instrument made under, an Act of the Scottish Parliament,
an enactment contained in, or in an instrument made under, a Measure or Act of the National Assembly for Wales, and
an enactment contained in, or in an instrument made under, Northern Ireland legislation;
“the FCA” means the Financial Conduct Authority;
“FSMA 2000” means the Financial Services and Markets Act 2000;
“the PRA” means the Prudential Regulation Authority.

P2para.Text: The Treasury may by order make such provision as they consider necessary or expedient for transitory, transitional or saving purposes in connection with the commencement of any provision made by or under this Act.
An order under this section may—

P3para.Text: confer functions on the FCA or the PRA;
modify, exclude or apply (with or without modifications) any enactment (including any provision of, or made under, this Act).

P1para.Text: The provisions of this Act extend to England and Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland, except that the amendments made by section 9 (preferential debts: Great Britain) have the same extent as the enactments amended.

P2para.Text: Sections 16 to 19 and this section come into force on the day on which this Act is passed.
The remaining provisions of this Act come into force on such day as the Treasury may by order appoint.
Different days may be appointed for different purposes.
This Act may be cited as the Financial Services (Banking Reform) Act 2013.

P1para.Text: Part 7 of FSMA 2000 (control of business transfer schemes) is amended as follows.
For “the authorised person concerned”, wherever occurring in Part 7 (including Schedule 12), substitute “the transferor concerned”.

P2para.Text: Section 103A (meaning of “the appropriate regulator”) is amended as follows.
In subsection (1), in paragraph (a), for “a scheme” substitute “a ring-fencing transfer scheme or a scheme (other than a ring-fencing transfer scheme)”.
At the end of subsection (2) insert—

P3para.Text: in the case of a ring-fencing transfer scheme, means the body to whose business the scheme relates.

P1para.Text: In section 106 (banking business transfer schemes), at the end of subsection (1)(c) insert “or a ring-fencing transfer scheme”.
After section 106A insert—

P2para.Text: A scheme is a ring-fencing transfer scheme if it—

P3para.Text: is one under which the whole or part of the business carried on—

P4para.Text: by a UK authorised person, or

P3para.Text: is to be transferred to another body (“the transferee”),
is to be made for one or more of the purposes mentioned in subsection (3), and
is not an excluded scheme or an insurance business transfer scheme.

P2para.Text: “Qualifying subsidiary” means a body which—

P3para.Text: is incorporated in the United Kingdom,
is a subsidiary undertaking of a UK authorised person, and
is not itself an authorised person.

P2para.Text: The purposes are—

P3para.Text: enabling a UK authorised person to carry on core activities as a ring-fenced body in compliance with the ring-fencing provisions;
enabling the transferee to carry on core activities as a ring-fenced body in compliance with the ring-fencing provisions;
making provision in connection with the implementation of proposals that would involve a body corporate whose group
includes the body corporate to whose business the scheme relates becoming a ring-fenced body while one or more other members of its group are not ring-fenced bodies.

P2para.Text: A scheme is an excluded scheme for the purposes of this section if—

P3para.Text: the body to whose business the scheme relates is a building society or credit union, or
the scheme is a compromise or arrangement to which Part 27 of the Companies Act 2006 (mergers and divisions of public companies) applies.

P2para.Text: For the purposes of subsection (1)(a) it is immaterial whether or not the business to be transferred is carried on in the United Kingdom.
“UK authorised person” has the same meaning as in section 105.
“Building society” and “credit union” have the same meanings as in section 106.
“The ring-fencing provisions” means ring-fencing rules and the duty imposed as a result of section 142G.
Section 107 (application for order sanctioning transfer scheme) is amended as follows.
In subsection (1), for “or a reclaim fund business transfer scheme” substitute “, a reclaim fund business transfer scheme or a ring-fencing transfer scheme”.
After subsection (2) insert—
An application relating to a ring-fencing transfer scheme may be made only with the consent of the PRA.
Section 110 (right to participate in proceedings) is amended as follows.
In subsection (1), after “section 107” insert “relating to an insurance business transfer scheme, a banking business transfer scheme or a reclaim fund business transfer scheme”.
After subsection (2) insert—
Subsections (4) and (5) apply where an application under section 107 relates to a ring-fencing transfer scheme.
The following are also entitled to be heard—

P3para.Text: the PRA,
where the transferee is an authorised person, the FCA, and
any person (“P”) (including an employee of the transferor concerned or of the transferee) who alleges that P would be adversely affected by the carrying out of the scheme.

P2para.Text: P is not entitled to be heard by virtue of subsection (4)(c) unless before the hearing P has—

P3para.Text: filed (in Scotland, lodged) with the court a written statement of the representations that P wishes the court to consider, and
served copies of the statement on the PRA and the transferor concerned.

P2para.Text: Section 111 (sanction of court for business transfer schemes) is amended as follows.
In subsection (1), for “or a reclaim fund business transfer scheme” substitute “, a reclaim fund business transfer scheme or a ring-fencing transfer scheme”.
In subsection (2), after paragraph (aa) insert—

P3para.Text: in the case of a ring-fencing transfer scheme, the appropriate certificates have been obtained (as to which see Part 2B of that Schedule);

P1para.Text: In section 112 (effect of order sanctioning business transfer scheme), in subsection (10), after “transfer scheme” insert “or ring-fencing transfer scheme”.
In section 112A (rights to terminate etc.), in subsection (1), for “or a banking business transfer scheme” substitute “, a banking business transfer scheme or a ring-fencing transfer scheme”.
In Schedule 12 (transfer schemes: certificates) after Part 2A insert—

P2para.Text: For the purposes of section 111(2) the appropriate certificates, in relation to a ring-fencing transfer scheme, are—

P3para.Text: a certificate given by the PRA certifying its approval of the application,
a certificate under paragraph 9C, and
if sub-paragraph (2) applies, a certificate under paragraph 9D.

P2para.Text: This sub-paragraph applies if the transferee is an EEA firm falling within paragraph 5(a) or (b) of Schedule 3.

A certificate under this paragraph is one given by the relevant authority and certifying that, taking the proposed transfer into account, the transferee possesses, or will possess before the scheme takes effect, adequate financial resources.
“Relevant authority” means—

P3para.Text: if the transferee is a PRA-authorised person with a Part 4A permission or with permission under Schedule 4, the PRA;
if the transferee is an EEA firm falling within paragraph 5(a) or (b) of Schedule 3, its home state regulator;

if the transferee does not fall within paragraph (a) or (b) but is subject to regulation in a country or territory outside the United Kingdom, the authority responsible for the supervision of the transferee’s business in the place in which the transferee has its head office;
in any other case, the FCA.

P2para.Text: In sub-paragraph (2), any reference to a transferee of a particular description includes a reference to a transferee who will be of that description if the proposed ring-fencing transfer scheme takes effect.

P1group.Title: Certificate as to consent of home state regulator

P1para.Text: A certificate under this paragraph is one given by the appropriate regulator and certifying that the home state regulator of the transferee has been notified of the proposed scheme and that—

P3para.Text: the home state regulator has responded to the notification, or
the period of 3 months beginning with the notification has elapsed.
